This is Jerusalem, our mother, the tem- ple of the Lord, the kingdom of heaven and the city of the Great King; and this whole church, as Augustine, Enchiridz’on, 41 [Nic. Fathers, 3 : 255, 256], says, “is to be understood not only of that part which sojourns here, praising God from the rising to the setting of the sun, and which, after its old cap- tivity, is singing the new song, but also of that part in heaven which, continuing true to the purpose for which it was con- stituted, has always been loyal to God, and has never felt misery from any fall. This part among the holy angels re- mains blessed and, as it behooves it to d0, helps the part so- journing upon the earth, because she who is to be one by the companionship of eternity is now also one by the bond of love. And this whole church was constituted to worship God. Therefore, neither the whole nor any part of it wishes to be worshipped as God.” So far, Augustine.
